lead_paragraph: Jobs with global powerhouses like Abbott are highly prized positions in India, but they can also put employees under inordinate pressure to cut corners, according to a Times investigation.

byline.contributor: Geeta Anand reported from Indore, India, and from New Delhi and Mumbai, and Frederik Joelving from Copenhagen. Suhasini Raj contributed reporting from New Delhi.
byline.original: By GEETA ANAND and FREDERIK JOELVING

headline.print_headline: Driven to Suicide by Pressure to Sell Medicine
headline.main: Driven to Suicide by an ‘Inhuman and Unnatural’ Pressure to Sell

snippet: Jobs with global powerhouses like Abbott are highly prized positions in India, but they can also put employees under inordinate pressure to cut corners, according to a Times investigation....
abstract: Suicide of 27-year-old salesman Ashish Awasthi in Indore, India, prompted by pressure from employer Abbot Laboratories to meet sales targets, has focused attention on company's aggressive sales policies; death led to walk out by 250 fellow employees; investigation by The New York Times has found Abbot managers pushed employees to secure sales at any cost.
